Premium DNA is a company formed by the same people that owned and operated Megalopolis Toys. They ended up scamming a ton of people, went under, and even got sued by Entertainment Earth (google it). They were using funds from preorders people placed on their Megalopolis retail site to fund their Premium DNA side company and fucked over everyone who ordered from the other site. People that didn't get fucked over forgave them because they wanted Premium DNA product and then act surprised when they get fucked over by these same scam artists.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10155279
Megalopolis was an online toy store that was heavily shilled for about a year across YouTube by various different "influencers." Shortly after obtaining a proper foothold, and getting some good word of mouth, they began promoting toys that would be exclusive to their store, under the Premium DNA brand. This included some big licenses, like Madballs.

Around July of 2020 people began to notice that they were getting charged for orders, but they weren't shipping (much like BBTS, you were not supposed to get charged until the item was about to ship). At first it seemed like some scamdemic problems, so people were understanding... but they kept doing it, and they wouldn't ship. This went on for months. I personally had my Great Ape Vegeta Figuarts figure through them, which is a reasonably expensive figure ($200~ish). They charged me, and then a month later I contacted them because it hadn't shipped. At first they were responsive, but after about three months they stopped responding to emails, and at that point I backcharged them after googling the issue and finding out that this was widespread. Word was that they were taking payments for figures that they never even ordered from the distributors, and apparently behind the scenes they ran up huge debts with said distributors, which they never paid. All of this eventually came to a head, and they shut down.

But Premium DNA came back, and claimed no actual connection to Megalopolis. They just said that they had a partnership, and since Megalopolis was gone, that was over. However people have done a deep dive on them, and found that it's all the same people who ran Megalopolis, which makes sense, because it was literally promoted as the Megalopolis house brand: https://creationedge.medium.com/the-story-of-toy-overlord-inc-f6e2e041c14a

Look, here is a press release from them: https://news.toyark.com/2020/07/23/megalopolis-announces-battletoads-clay-fighter-and-earthworm-jim-and-more-retro-action-figures-396294

last_replies.name: Gelgoog Guy
last_replies.com:
So with our 19th Groupbuild coming to a close, we now approach the 20th. Since it's a bit of a milestone and I've been running these for a little over 6 years now, I felt that we should do something a little special this time around. Instead of the typical structure of taking ideas from the posters ITT and polling them to decide what theme to do for the next few months, we're going to have something I'm gonna call the "Groupbuild Groupbuild". The rules are as follows:
>Have a build that you never got to finish for a previous groupbuild? Only started building recently and sad you missed out on a theme from 4-5 years ago? Now's an opportunity to get that build done!
>Your build must conform to at least one of the previous 19 Groupbuild themes and the rules of that groupbuild, though you can mix together elements of other past groupbuilds (ie: a Melee Zaku or a mecha musume sniper)
>You must detail what theme(s) your build is going for when you submit your build.
>You can't submit a touched-up version of a previous groupbuild entry, but you can build something that fits alongside your past build (ie: a 2nd squad member for an entry to the GM groupbuild or a mid-season upgrade/powered up version of the same suit) so long as you showcase both the old and new builds in a few photos.
For information on the rules of past Groupbuilds, please refer to this pastebin: https://pastebin.com/xXqM1Tg0 (embed)

All other standard Groupbuild rules apply (Must be a model kit, must have some WIP photos included in the email along with a short bio describing it).

START - 11/6/22
END - 2/28/22

threads.name: Santa Man
threads.com:
It's November 1st, so you know what that means. It's time for /toy/ Secret Santa 2022!

There doesn't appear to be as many shipping delays this year but I'm still making the cut off for sign up November 6th like last year because it worked out well and gives everyone through the weekend to sign up. I will try to have assignments out by the 7th or the 8th at the latest.

There are some small changes to SS this year though:
>The budget has been changed from 25-35 usd to 30-40 usd
>Proof of purchase will now require you to send me a picture of your gift with a timestamp before I give it the ok along with the receipt
>I will not be pairing up Canadians domestically due to issues in the past. Those who wish to ship domestic will be paired with people in the US. Sorry for the inconvenience.

For more info on these changes check the FAQ as I've detailed it there for the exception of the price change because the explanation for that is very simple. I picked out the original 25-35 price range several years ago and after years of running the event I felt bumping the price up by 5 dollars better reflects what people actually spend on the event, that's all.

My email: toysecretsanta2022@gmail.com
Sign-up form: https://forms.gle/yXbEEiFmu8t1xTs77
FAQ: https://pastebin.com/jA4SUZUQ

threads.name: Morphine-Kun
threads.com:
Welcome back everyone, hope you're all doing well.

The time has come for us to finally have new releases in the line! By now most of everyone who ordered Olivier and Vania should have them in hand. Its seems the delay was worth it as Olivier seems to be one of the better releases in the line. Vania also seems to be a generally good release as people are having fun messing with her and Olivier. As of now, we only have one other figure up for Pre-Order right now, that being Bikini Clover. Currently we know that the Polynian and Touhou series will continue since Marisa is supposedly the next in line to go up. The official Poly 4Koma is still going and it seems its been well received as it gives little look into the everyday lives of the Polys we know. We also had a wonderful surprise in the form of the new Polynian MLL body! We finally have a counterpart to the Iana body. Aside from that things have been pretty quiet for the time being.

As always, here is the assistance e-mail for those who need it, so if any problem should arise, feel free to contact them over at "user_support@mile-stone.jp" or the shop you purchased the figure from.

Once again, feel free to share your photos and adventures, they add life and some fun to the thread. Also, welcome newcomers, we hope you enjoy your stay.

last_replies.com: Heman has about a dozen variants. With the classics being thunder punch, flying fists, battle armor, laser light, new adventures, and snake armor. Superman has just as many variations and almost the same number of equally iconic redesigns and costume iterations. In my ideal Superman line, you'd see the fleischer suit, the wayne/swan classic suit, the regeneration suit, a color change figure that served as both superman red and superman blue, and the kingdom come suit. In turn this would leave room for Superman's answers to Faker, Slime Pit, and AE He-man who would be Cyborg Superman, Bizarro, and Ultraman. last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10155950
>>10155958
Both of these issues feed into each other. Superman's iconography isn't as tailor-made to move merch the way Batman's is, so the designers don't do the deep diving necessary to make a Superman toyline as immersive and fun as it should be. Not to mention most toylines use a series or movie as a springboard, so the chances to do a solid evergreen line that does Superman's slice of the universe justice are notable slim in comparison.

Ironically they have an excellent chance to try harder with that Superman cartoon coming out next year, but considering how disparate new series are with toylines (and merchandise in general) it will most likely be squandered.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10149722
I agree with the above poster, White Noise is probably objectively the best.

I will also submit a side vote for Ricochet. Since I was a kid I specifically wanted a super articulated boxing kangaroo figure, and somewhat improbably, that's exactly what I got some ~15 years later. This mold is great fun, with much better range of motion than I was expecting. The little joey (who is apparently the one actually named Ricochet, the kangaroo is just his mech suit) can be stored away in the belly, and has rudimentary articulation himself. The boxing gloves and visor are also removable if you want a "plain" robot kangaroo.

The only downside is I remember the transformation being kind of too complex and fiddly to be fun. I say "remember" because I had a bad time with it the first time, and haven't transformed it since. It's truly amazing as a figure, but if you're looking for one that's fun to transform back and forth repeatedly, this might not be the one.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
Roarmeo is incredible.

He's a lanky fella, big for a BB. 10/10 deco. Articulation is crazy, he's packed with joints and you can get him to move all over the place, be bipedal, even take some pretty wide stances, which is frequently tough for organic quadrupedal toys. Nothing loose fortunately, but he has some ratcheting joints that are frustratingly stiff. Would highly recommend overall, go buy him. He's one of the greats.

>>10152986
There's a few ways to do it. The best way if you're only going to run them together is to make the first bit of CV29 equal to 1 (i.e. add one to the current value of CV29). This will reverse the direction of the locomotive. You can also consist them or set them both to the same address and one will always be in reverse.
I'm pretty sure there is also a setting to reverse a loco if you consist them together.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
We had a really comfy LOTR toys thread here a while ago. As said before, the original line from 2001-2005 still holds up really well, especially some of the later figures when Toybiz started moving away from action gimmicks to 30POA (they're essentially Marvel Legends style figures), and they're actually still quite affordable to collect, with a few exceptions (the Balrog).

There's not really a lot of new stuff to talk about with LOTR toys although Diamond Select did just come out with their 8" deluxe figures. There's no toys for "that show" and there probably won't be (good riddance). Once in a while it's nice to have a thread to catch up on how fellow LOTR anons' collections are going though. What scenes do you want to recreate? Are you army building? Doing any customs and conversions to complete your collection? Have you come across any cool boomer LOTR merch from before the movies? Let's take a moment to celebrate that this beloved book series got the action figure line it deserved.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
Dumb stuff you did with your toys when you were little?

When I was like 8 I got the four good guys and one of the bad guys as a present, I wasn't into the line, and I found the actual characters boring, but the little dudes that came with them, for some reason I liked their designs better so I played with them more.

I imagined they were super heroes. The yellow one with the visor above his head I imagined was team leader. He had Superman's power set, except he could shoot various kinds of lasers, not just heat. The orange one I imagined having Wolverine's powerset, but also a set of robotic, mecha powers. The blue one I imagined having a full suite of psychic powers and super human intelligence. The green one, largely because of his pose, I imagined had super speed and various speed related powers, like flight and invulnerability. From the villains, I had the fourth one, the little light purple bug. I imagined he could teleport, shapeshift and had stretching powers, and he was a wild card element that sometimes worked with the others and sometimes against them.

Toyline general info:
>http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Figma

Max Factory figma list & blog
>http://www.figma.jp/en/figma
>http://ameblo.jp/figma/
>http://www.goodsmile.info/en/products/category/figma

Reviews and news about GSC/MF products by Kahotan
>http://mikatan.goodsmile.info/en/
>http://ameblo.jp/gsc-mikatan/

Where to buy
>GSC Online Shop - some figmas only are available through their online shop
>Amiami - usual place for buying, to some people, shipping is a bit higher due to packaging
>Hobby Link Japan shipping is usual lower, but their prices are a bit higher, private warehaouse is available
>Hobby Search Japan - items stay in stock the longest
>Mandarake - search figma or フィグマ
>eBay/Amazon - only if you hate having too much money. Avoid bootlegs, you can spot them as 'Chinese version'
>http://jungle-scs.co.jp/ - Seems like you can fine some good deals here
>Check the BST threads, My Figure Collection for any offer/deal

Here's a link to the buyfag guide list of shops:
http://www.buyfags.moe/Full_guide#List_of_shops
If you're getting into the hobby, there's plenty of other useful information to find on the wiki.

In case someone is interested in the printable backdrops/dioramas & other papercraft stuff that Max Factory have in the download section of their site:
>http://www.maxfactory.jp/ja/mxf-downloads
here is a back up, Enjoy!
>https://www.mediafire.com/?7l9ar0z58cx43sa

Short illustrated posing guide by Max Factory
>http://ameblo.jp/figma/entry-11564427757.html (in moonrunes)
The S shape is always good advice though. The basic idea is that straight lines tend to look stiff.

Problems when swapping parts/accessories with your figmas? Check this advice
>http://www.goodsmile.info/en/post/3325

Tomytec's 1 inch scale section (1/12 stuff, little armory, vehicles and others)
>http://www.tomytec.co.jp/1inch/

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10138805
to list a few:

1) No one-brain-brick gui, only a bunch of LEDs, even the original RCX had a way to select programs.

2) Teal can be hard to integrate with existing collections to make something that looks cohesive.

3) Has 6 ports instead of 7 like the previous version, and while the RCX only had 3 ports, you could stack motors on a single port.

4) Worse specs, it runs at 100mhz, with room for 30 programs and 32mb of storage, while the previous version was 300mhz (and could be overclocked to 400mhz) and had an SD card slot.

5) cables are permanently connected to the motors and sensors, meaning if any part of that cable gets damaged you have to replace the entire thing.

6) No backwards compatability, Ev3 could use NXT motors (but not sensors), and there were first and third party adapters adapters for RCX motors, and the new one is incapable of using any of these.

7) A somewhat more minor issues, but it comes with a 4th motor instead of a touch sensor, severely limiting capabilities out of the box.


All in all, it's pretty crap.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10150834
>open it
>JJ Abrams jumps out and punches you in the nuts

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
You need to limit yourself. The limitations will give you room to decide on the relative value of one thing compared to another.
Compare:
>I want every Beatles record in good quality vinyl version
>I want anything and everything to do with the Beatles; vinyl, cassette tapes, throw pillows, posters, bottle openers etc.
One is a dedicated, focussed collection. The other is a pile of money and space wasting shit.

If you don't know how, start through your budget. Start at 0 dollars and add a small monthly amount to that. It needs to be way less than you are currently spending.
If you commit to spending a decided amount, you will start to choose out of necessity.
As you start to choose, realize some collections you started are not going to get finished.
Sell what won't get finished, at most keeping a single "pipedream" collection that you slowly build out.
Once a year, consider selling off whole lines/collections to add to the budget for things that you value more.

A second limitation that works very well and that very much compliments the above is to limit space.
Dedicate less space to display. Especially don't make an entire room your display room, but make one display in your living space, one in your office/gaming space and one in your bedroom... Or even just do living and office space. Make it ELEGANT instead of BIG. Make it look like you are not ashamed of it if say a romantic interest, coworker or parent comes to visit.
By limiting shelf space, you again make yourself differentiate between what you value most and what you merely kind of like. You can absolutely use shelf space to rotate interesting pieces that are temporary. Dont forget to limit your storage as well. Anything stored away for a year or longer gets sold. If you really want to keep something, display it and store something else.

If you limit your budget and your space, you will learn how you did not actually love all of it equally. And you will be more in control as a hobbyist.

I started selling my shit because I don't have the space and anytime I move it's a huge mess. I decided to only keep one character of my all time favorite franchises in 1/12 scale. For other shit I like I try to find 1/18 scale figures so that they can be in a display here it makes sense that they're all in a crowd.
In general I bought one bookshelf and \I don't ever want to expand, if I can't keep it in my bookshelf it's too much and I decide what I want and don't want.

It's difficult since like it or not you do form an attachment to plastic and it's hard to get rid of it. Especially when you are selling at a loss and you like it more than what little money they give you, but you gotta stop being a hoarder and sell it. While it sucks the peace of mind of not having tons of figures is very freeing. I don't usually regret selling stuff, it's only been a few that I regret but that's ok, they can always be rebought if I really want them.
Hoarding is not cool /toy/bros, wish I had had more restraint when I was younger.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
This dude right here. I can use almost any decent figure to figure out a pose and the foreshortening. Knowing all those attachment points is what really works for a good drawing.

He’s 20 bucks on amazon and i did the greywash myself.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
As a professional artist who's been doing this for a decade plus at this point, you don't buy a figure. None of them properly display things like musculature or really do anything than give you a basic idea and starting point. There's a reason that the classical drawing figure is basic shapes. If you need or want more than that, don't spend money on getting some figure that'll still not do what you actually need it to do when you don't have anatomical knowledge.
Pirate or buy CSP and use the 3d models as a basis. You can either use them for reference on a separate canvas or trace over them. You can adjust lighting direction and intensity, focus and perspective, change proportions and have control over as many bones as you could generally want in a 3d model for this kinda thing. It's far easier and better than any figure I've ever had for reference and you can also stick it into other 3d environments as well as apply objects to the character and said environments.

>>10150920
This is also one of the only useful things in this regard, because it lets you quickly check where and how muscles sit.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10149604
im tempted for the Waifu figure. but that 3D printed quality looks fragile as fuck.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10150920
>>10150947
Muscles shift, stretch, squish and move around drastically depending on pose, knowing where they are and how they look in the one neutral position is of little help. It's probably best to find as may nude pose references as possible from all kinds of angles and analyze the differences yourself for future application in drawing. To me personally, studying skeletal structure was more important than muscles because the skeleton stays consistent in all poses and by knowing the bones you can more or less figure out the correct behavior of muscles that overlay them.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10150947
XNALara let's you do this for free too but you can use models ripped from videogames if you want a specific character. Not the best but I've used it when I wanted to see outfits from different angles or unusual designs, headdresses, etc.

Nice job anon! Contrary to what plamo general says it's completely fine to paint on bare plastic and top coat all that. On that topic, I'd advice you to paint details before glosscoat, because then you can scratch excess paint off of the model. Looking at that front skirt piece, I get what you were going for there, but the edges of the red area could've been trimmed using something like a cocktail stick for a sharper end result. Same goes for the panel lines.
Plamo general is a good source of inspiration but they'll grill you for not painting 100% of the kit. But you just do your own thing and have fun anon.
Btw here's something I did with a similar gm kit.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>10149121
Your wasting time and money doing a gloss coat over bare plastic. Despite what 'pro modelers' tell you, they are just reading the script and assume you have an airbrush and hundreds in paints and supplies to do the whole shebang. The only reason to use a gloss coat is to protect a fully painted kits painted layer so you can panel line on top of it without smearing/staining. That's the reason your gundam marker panel lines look so thick, it sticks to the gloss coat and doesn't allow your finger oils/qtips thin the line. You basically can't use gundam markers with a gloss coat, only tamiya panel line accent because it can be cleaned with lighter fluid without damaging the gloss coat.

Really bugs me how everyone parrots the "gloss coat before panel lining!" line without mentioning that this should only be done if you plan on fully painting the kit with an airbrush or at least a wide assortment of rattle cans. Next time properly thin your panel lines with your fingers/qtips(for gundam marker, or q-tips and lighter fluid for tamiya) on the bare plastic and go straight to the matte topcoat. If you insist on gloss coating bare plastic for whatever reason, discard the gundam marker and exclusively use tamiya panel line accent.
